Welcome to Space Weather’s documentation!¶

Analysis¶

Canonical Correlation Analysis¶

spaceweather.analysis.cca.cca(ds, detrend='linear')¶

Run canonical correlation analysis between stations.

Parameters

  • ds (xarray.Dataset) – Data as converted by supermag.mag_csv_to_Dataset().

  • detrend (str or bool, optional) – Type of detrending to perform on ds prior to running canonical correlation analysis. If False is input, detrending will not occur. Default is linear.

Returns

Dataset containing the canonical correlation analysis attributes.

The data_vars are: coeffs, weights, ang_rel, ang_abs, comps.

The coordinates are: first_st, second_st, component, index, ab, uv.

Return type

xarray.Dataset

spaceweather.analysis.cca.cca_coeffs(ds)¶

Calculate the first canonical correlation coefficients between stations.

Parameters

ds (xarray.Dataset) – Data as converted by supermag.mag_csv_to_Dataset().

Returns

Dataset containing the first canonical correlation coefficients.

The data_vars are: cca_coeffs.

The coordinates are: first_st, second_st.

Return type

xarray.Dataset

Data Functions¶

spaceweather.analysis.data_funcs.csv_to_Dataset(csv_file, components=['N', 'E', 'Z'], MLT=True, MLAT=True)¶

Restructure the SuperMAG data as an xarray Dataset.

Returns an xarray Dataset with time as the first dimension.

Parameters

  • csv_file (csv file) – CSV file downloaded from the SuperMAG website.

  • components (list, optional) – List of components in the data. Default is [‘N’, ‘E’, ‘Z’].

  • MLT (bool, optional) – True if MLT data is included in csv_file, False otherwise.

  • MLAT (bool, optional) – True if MLAT data is included in csv_file, False otherwise.

Returns

Dataset with the SuperMAG data easily accessible.

The data_vars are: measurements, mlts, mlats.

The coordinates are: time, component, station.

Return type

xarray.Dataset

spaceweather.analysis.data_funcs.detrend(ds, type='linear')¶

Detrend the time series for each component.

Parameters

  • ds (xarray.Dataset) – Data as converted by supermag.mag_csv_to_Dataset().

  • type (str, optional) – Type of detrending passed to scipy detrend. Default is ‘linear’.

Returns

Dataset with the SuperMAG data easily accessible.

The data_vars are: measurements.

The coordinates are: time, component, station.

Return type

xarray.Dataset

spaceweather.analysis.data_funcs.window(ds, win_len=128)¶

Window the time series for a given window length.

Parameters

  • ds (xarray.Dataset) – Data as converted by supermag.mag_csv_to_Dataset().

  • win_len (int, optional) – Length of window in minutes. Default is 128.

Returns

Dataset with the SuperMAG data easily accessible and an extra dimension from windowing.

The data_vars are: measurements, mlts, mlats.

The coordinates are: time, component, station, window.

Return type

xarray.Dataset

Generating Model Data¶

Thresholding¶

spaceweather.analysis.threshold.thresh_dods(ds, n0=0.25)¶

Calculate the threshold for each station pair, method used in Dods et al (2015) paper.

This function follows the outline in the Dods et al (2015) paper.

Parameters

  • ds (xarray.Dataset) – Data as converted by supermag.mag_csv_to_Dataset().

  • n0 (float, optional) – The desired expected normalized degree of each station. Default is 0.25.

Returns

Dataset containing the thresholds for each station pair.

The data_vars are: thresholds.

The coordinates are: first_st, second_st.

Return type

xarray.Dataset

spaceweather.analysis.threshold.thresh_kf(ds)¶

Calculate the threshold for each station pair, my method.

This function simply uses the first canonical correlation coefficients across the entire time series for each station pair.

Parameters

ds (xarray.Dataset) – Data as converted by supermag.mag_csv_to_Dataset().

Returns

Dataset containing the thresholds for each station pair.

The data_vars are: thresholds.

The coordinates are: first_st, second_st.

Return type

xarray.Dataset

spaceweather.analysis.threshold.threshold_ds(ds, win_len=128, n0=0.25)¶

Calculate the threshold for each station pair, using a windowed approach.

This function windows the Dataset and then follows the outline in the Dods et al (2015) paper for calculating the pairwise thresholds in each window.

Parameters

  • ds (xarray.Dataset) – Data as converted by supermag.mag_csv_to_Dataset().

  • win_len (int, optional) – Length of window in minutes. Default is 128.

  • n0 (float, optional) – The desired expected normalized degree of each station. Default is 0.25.

Returns

Dataset containing the thresholds for each station pair.

The data_vars are: thresholds.

The coordinates are: first_st, second_st, win_start.

Return type

xarray.Dataset

Heatmaps¶

spaceweather.visualisation.heatmaps.adj_mat(ds, ds_win, n0=0.25, ret=True)¶

Calculate and plot the adjacency matrix for a set of stations during one time window.

This function follows the outline in the Dods et al (2015) paper for calculating the pairwise thresholds. It then determines adjacency by comparing the correlations in the specified window of the dataset to the above thresholds.

Parameters

  • ds (xarray.Dataset) – Data as converted by supermag.mag_csv_to_Dataset(). This is used to calculate the pairwise thresholds.

  • ds_win (xarray.Dataset) – Data as converted by supermag.mag_csv_to_Dataset(). This window of a Dataset is used to calculate the pairwise correlations, for comparison with the above pairwise thresholds.

  • n0 (float, optional) – The desired expected normalized degree of each station. Default is 0.25.

  • ret (bool, optional) – Boolean value of whether or not to return related objects. The objects are the adjacency matrix and heatmap. Default is True.

Returns

  • xarray.Dataset –

    Dataset containing the adjacency coefficients.

    The data_vars are: adj_coeffs.

    The coordinates are: first_st, second_st.

  • matplotlib.figure.Figure – Plot of the adjacency matrix.

spaceweather.visualisation.heatmaps.correlogram(ds, station1=None, station2=None, lag_range=10, win_len=128, ret=True)¶

Calculate and plot a heatmap of correlations between two stations over time windows and lag.

Parameters

  • ds (xarray.Dataset) – Data as converted by supermag.mag_csv_to_Dataset().

  • station1 (str, optional) – Station for which the time window is fixed. If no station is provided, this will default to the first station in ds.

  • station2 (str, optional) – Station for which the time window will be shifted according to lag_range. If no station is provided, this will default to the second station in ds.

  • lag_range (int, optional) – The range, in minutes, of positive and negative shifts for station2. Default is 10.

  • win_len (int, optional) – Length of window in minutes. Default is 128.

  • ret (bool, optional) – Boolean value of whether or not to return related objects. The objects are time, lag, correlations, and figure. Default is True.

Returns

  • range – Range of times used in the correlogram.

  • range – Range of lags used in the correlogram.

  • numpy.ndarray – Numpy array of correlations.

  • matplotlib.figure.Figure – Plot of the correlogram; ie heatmap of correlations.

Line Plots of Data¶

spaceweather.visualisation.lines.plot_mag_data(ds)¶

Plot components of data like on the SuperMAG website.

Parameters

ds (xarray.Dataset) – Data as converted by supermag.mag_csv_to_Dataset().

Yields

NoneType – One column of plots, where each plot shows the components of one station over time.

Spectral Analysis¶

spaceweather.visualisation.spectral_analysis.power_spectrum(ts=None, ds=None, station=None, component=None)¶

Plot the power spectrum of the Fourier transform of the time series. It is recommended to use a small amount of the time series for best results.

Parameters

  • ts (xarray.Dataset, optional) – Data as converted by supermag.mag_csv_to_Dataset(). Can be replaced by including ds, station, and component inputs. Timeseries of one component in one station.

  • ds (xarray.Dataset, optional) – Data as converted by supermag.mag_csv_to_Dataset(). This will be used to extract a timeseries of the same form as the ts input.

  • station (string, optional) – Three letter code for the station to be used in the extraction of timeseries from ds input.

  • component (string, optional) – Component to be used in the extraction of timeseries from ds input.

Yields

matplotlib.figure.Figure – Plot of the power spectrum. This may be a list of lines?

spaceweather.visualisation.spectral_analysis.spectrogram(ts=None, ds=None, station=None, component=None, win_len=128, win_olap=None)¶

Plot a spectrogram for one component of one station.

Parameters

  • ts (xarray.Dataset, optional) – Data as converted by supermag.mag_csv_to_Dataset(). Can be replaced by including ds, station, and component inputs. Timeseries of one component in one station.

  • ds (xarray.Dataset, optional) – Data as converted by supermag.mag_csv_to_Dataset(). This will be used to extract a timeseries of the same form as the ts input.

  • station (string, optional) – Three letter code for the station to be used in the extraction of timeseries from ds input.

  • component (string, optional) – Component to be used in the extraction of timeseries from ds input.

  • win_len (int, optional) – Length of the window. Default is 128 (minutes).

  • win_olap (int, optional) – Length of the overlap of consecutive windows. Default is win_len - 1 for a new window every minute.

Yields

matplotlib.figure.Figure – Plot of the spectrogram. This may be a NoneType?
